[[2022 MLS Cup Playoffs|Playoffs]]: First round | current = 2022 Inter Miami CF season | kit_alt1 = | pattern_la1 = _intermiami22h | pattern_b1 = _intermiami22H | pattern_ra1 = _intermiami22h | pattern_sh1 = _intermiami22h | pattern_so1 = _color_3_stripes_black | leftarm1 = F5B6CD | body1 = F5B6CD | rightarm1 = F5B6CD | shorts1 = F5B6CD | socks1 = F5B6CD | kit_alt2 = | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = _shoulder_stripes_black_shirt | pattern_ra2 = | pattern_sh2 = _adidasonblack | pattern_so2 = _color_3_stripes_on_black | leftarm2 = 000000 | body2 = F7B5CD | rightarm2 = 000000 | shorts2 = F7B5CD | socks2 = F7B5CD | website = https://www.intermiamicf.com/ }} {{Squads sidebar |main=Inter Miami CF |team1=Inter Miami CF |league1=MLS |team2=Inter Miami CF II |league2=MLS Next Pro }} '''Club Internacional de Fútbol Miami''', known as '''Inter Miami CF''' or simply '''Inter Miami''', is an American professional [[association football|soccer]] club based in the [[Miami metropolitan area]].{{cite news|title=MLS Miami expansion team unveils name, crest|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/09/05/mls-miami-expansion-team-unveils-name-crest|website=MLSSoccer.com|publisher=MLS Digital|date=September 5, 2018|access-date=September 5, 2018}} Established in 2018, the club began to play in [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) in the [[2020 Major League Soccer season|2020 season]]. The club currently plays its home MLS matches at [[DRV PNK Stadium]], the site of the former [[Lockhart Stadium]] in nearby [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]]. ==History== In November 2012, MLS commissioner [[Don Garber]] confirmed the league's renewed interest in placing an expansion franchise in Miami,{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/soccer-insider/wp/2012/11/26/mls-commissioners-state-of-league/|title=MLS commissioner's state of league|date= November 26, 2012|work=Soccer Insider|first=Steven|last=Goff}} after the [[Miami Fusion]] folded following the [[2001 Major League Soccer season|2001 season]] and an expansion bid led by Miami-based Bolivian telecom entrepreneur [[Marcelo Claure]] and [[FC Barcelona]] failed in 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/1110/major-league-soccer/2009/03/03/1137156/miami-barcelona-mls-campaign-is-dead|title=Miami Barcelona MLS Campaign Is Dead |work=[[Goal.com]] |date=March 3, 2009}} When [[David Beckham]], who had received an option to purchase an expansion team at a price of $25 million when he joined the league in 2007,{{cite news|url=http://www.socceramerica.com/article/51723/beckham-is-mls-expansion-story-du-jour.html|title=Beckham is MLS expansion story du jour|first=Paul|last=Kennedy|date=May 20, 2013|work=Soccer Business Insider}} ended his playing career in April 2013, the league held preliminary discussions with Beckham's advisers about several expansion targets, including Miami.{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/soccer-beckham-talking-mls-owning-team-193804208.html|agency=Reuters|publisher=Yahoo!|title=Soccer-Beckham talking to MLS about owning a new team|date=May 17, 2013|first=Simon|last=Evans}} That same year, other investors, including Italian financier Alessandro Butini{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/10/02/3663306_david-beckham-group-still-working.html|title=David Beckham group still working on Miami MLS bid; competing group emerges|date= October 2, 2013|work=The Miami Herald|first=Michelle|last=Kaufman}} and [[Miami Dolphins]] owner [[Stephen M. Ross]] expressed interest in owning a Miami franchise as well.{{cite news|url=http://soccer.si.com/2013/10/02/mls-expansion-miami-alessandro-butini-david-beckham/ |title=Alessandro Butini is the latest suitor in MLS' Miami expansion project |work=Planet Fútbol |date=October 2, 2013 |access-date=October 11, 2013}} In his December 2013 State of the League address, Garber identified Beckham and [[Simon Fuller]] as potential owners in Miami.{{cite news|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/mlscup/2013/news/article/2013/12/03/major-league-soccer-commissioner-don-garber-discusses-expansion-scheduling-l|title=MLS commissioner Don Garber discusses expansion, scheduling in latest State of the League address|date=December 3, 2013|first=Simon|last=Borg|work=MLSsoccer.com|publisher=Major League Soccer}} Later that month, on December 17, [[Government of Miami-Dade County#Board of County Commissioners|Miami-Dade County commissioners]] voted unanimously to allow Mayor [[Carlos A. Giménez]] to negotiate with the Beckham-led group on a new stadium in downtown Miami.{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/12/17/3823998/miami-dade-commission-oks-major.html|title=Miami-Dade commissioners sound gung-ho about David Beckham's potential Major League Soccer stadium|date=December 17, 2013|first=Patricia|last= Mazzei|work=The Miami Herald|access-date=January 2, 2014}} The league announced that Beckham exercised his option on February 5, 2014,{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2014/02/03/3908896/beckham-miami-deal-one-step-closer.htmlg|title=Beckham-Miami deal one step closer; local visit plans revealed|first=Michelle|last=Kaufman|work=The Miami Herald|date=February 2, 2014}} and that Miami Beckham United,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/mar/24/david-beckham-port-miami-stadium-plans-mls|title=David Beckham's grand plan for Port Miami stadium for new MLS team|first=Chris|last=Smith|work=The Guardian|date=March 24, 2014|access-date=March 25, 2014}} the investment group led by Beckham, Fuller and Claure, would own an expansion franchise in Miami, assuming that financing for a stadium could be agreed upon.{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2014/02/05/3914127/soccer-star-david-beckham-to-bring.html|title=Soccer star David Beckham to bring MLS team to Miami|work=The Miami Herald|first=Patricia|last=Mazzei|date=February 5, 2014}} In presentations to officials and potential investors, the ownership group used "Miami Vice" and "Miami Current" as [[working title]]s for the club.{{cite news|work=The Palm Beach Post|title=Photos: possible logo, uniforms for David Beckham's Miami MLS club?|date=February 12, 2014|url=http://blogs.palmbeachpost.com/caneswatch/2014/02/12/miami-david-beckham-mls-team-name-logos-kit/|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140215041338/http://blogs.palmbeachpost.com/caneswatch/2014/02/12/miami-david-beckham-mls-team-name-logos-kit/|archive-date=February 15, 2014}} After its initial stadium proposals fell through, Commissioner Garber reiterated in August 2014 that the expansion would not be approved until a downtown stadium plan was secured.{{cite news | title = David Beckham's Miami MLS plans on hold until stadium secured | work = Sports Illustrated | date=July 29, 2014| url = https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2014/07/29/mls-miami-downtown-stadium-david-beckham | access-date = August 4, 2014 }} Beckham bought Fuller out in May 2019.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikeozanian/2019/05/10/david-beckham-reportedly-buys-stake-in-his-company-at-150-million-valuation/|title=David Beckham Reportedly Buys Stake In His Company At $150 Million Valuation|first=Mike|last=Ozanian|website=Forbes}} On January 29, 2018, the Miami Beckham United group, four years after the ownership's original announcement of pursuing a team, was awarded the twenty-fifth MLS franchise and was set to launch in the 2020 season.{{cite news|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/01/29/its-official-major-league-soccer-awards-expansion-team-miami|title=It's official: Major League Soccer awards expansion team to Miami|date=January 29, 2018|access-date=January 31, 2018|website=MLSSoccer.com|publisher=MLS Digital}}{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/major-league-soccer/story/3361118/mls-finally-announces-david-beckhams-expansion-team-in-miami|title=MLS announces David Beckham's expansion team in Miami|date=January 29, 2018|access-date=September 12, 2018|publisher=[[ESPN]]}} The announcement represented part of a larger MLS expansion that would increase its number of teams to 26 by 2020 and 30 after that. Since Beckham's original announcement of his intention to place a team in Miami in 2014, [[Orlando City SC|Orlando City]], [[New York City FC]], [[Atlanta United FC|Atlanta United]], [[Minnesota United FC|Minnesota United]], [[Los Angeles FC]], and [[FC Cincinnati]] have all begun MLS play. Paul McDonough was hired as sporting director effective August 4.{{Cite web | title=Miami MLS hires Paul McDonough from Atlanta to be Sporting Director | author=Tom Bogert | work=MLSsoccer.com | date=August 2, 2018 | access-date=August 15, 2018 | url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/08/02/miami-mls-hires-paul-mcdonough-sporting-director }} [[File:Gonzalo Higuaín 2019.jpg|thumb|upright|Argentine [[Gonzalo Higuaín]] signed with Miami in 2020]] The team's ownership now operates through Miami Freedom Park LLC. Some graphics used by the group have evoked the [[Freedom Tower (Miami)|Freedom Tower]], a city landmark.{{cite web|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/article211712754.html|title=David Beckham's Miami MLS team might finally have a name|website=[[Miami Herald]] |access-date=August 20, 2018}} ''Club Internacional de Fútbol Miami'', or ''Inter Miami CF'' for short, was announced as the club's name on September 5, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45419289|title=Inter Miami: David Beckham's MLS team is called Club Internacional de Futbol Miami|date=September 5, 2018|publisher=BBC}} On December 30, 2019, former [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay national team]] player and [[C.F. Monterrey]] manager [[Diego Alonso]] was announced as the club's inaugural head coach.{{cite web|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/en/post/2019/12/30/inter-miami-cf-selects-diego-alonso-first-ever-head-coach-club-history|title=Inter Miami CF Selects Diego Alonso as First-Ever Head Coach in Club History|publisher=Inter Miami CF|date=December 30, 2019|access-date=December 30, 2019}}{{cite news|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/inter-miami/article238819133.html|title=Inter Miami 'blocks out noise,' hires Uruguayan Diego Alonso as first head coach|work=The Miami Herald|first=Michelle|last=Kaufman|date=December 30, 2019}} Inter Miami's first MLS game was played on March 1, 2020, losing 1–0, away to [[Los Angeles FC]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.goal.com/en/news/vela-and-lafc-give-beckhams-inter-miami-a-lesson-on-the/tur7fix5wgsc1df1sz58hfuoh|title=Vela and LAFC give Beckham's Inter Miami a lesson on the importance of a superstar scorer {{!}} Goal.com|website=www.goal.com|access-date=March 2, 2020}} [[Designated Player Rule|Designated Player]] [[Rodolfo Pizarro]] scored the first goal in Inter Miami history the following game on March 7, in a 2–1 loss to [[D.C. United]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/inter-miami/article241005031.html|title=Takeaways from Inter Miami's drama-filled 2-1 road loss to D.C. United|last=Kaufman|first=Michelle|website=[[Miami Herald]] |date=March 8, 2020}} Their first home match was supposed to be on March 14, 2020, against [[LA Galaxy]], Beckham's former club. The match has since been delayed due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19 pandemic]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/inter-miami/article241111236.html|title=The Inter Miami home opener is on hold as MLS suspends season due to the coronavirus|last=Kaufman|first=Michelle|date=March 12, 2020|website=Miami Herald|access-date=April 27, 2020}} On August 23, 2020, Inter Miami recorded their first franchise victory, 3–2 over [[Orlando City SC|Orlando City]].{{cite web |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2020/08/23/inter-miami-overcome-five-months-suffering-first-mls-win-we-had-wait |title=Inter Miami overcome five months of suffering with first MLS win: "We had to wait" |website=MLS Soccer |date=August 23, 2020 }} On January 18, 2021, [[England women's national football team|England Women]]'s manager [[Phil Neville]] was appointed as the new head coach, and [[Seattle Sounders FC]]'s [[Chris Henderson]] as chief soccer officer and sporting director.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/55705395 |title=England: Phil Neville leaves Lionesses manager role |publisher=BBC Sport |date=January 18, 2021 |access-date=January 18, 2021}}{{cite news|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/en/post/2021/01/18/inter-miami-cf-names-phil-neville-head-coach|title=Inter Miami CF Names Phil Neville as Head Coach |publisher=Inter Miami CF |date=January 18, 2021 |access-date=January 18, 2021}}{{cite news|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/en/post/2021/01/18/inter-miami-cf-appoints-chris-henderson-chief-soccer-officer-and-sporting-director|title= Inter Miami CF Appoints Chris Henderson as Chief Soccer Officer and Sporting Director |publisher=Inter Miami CF |date=January 18, 2021 |access-date=January 18, 2021}} On May 28, 2021, MLS announced that it would sanction Inter Miami CF, owner Jorge Mas, and former sporting director Paul McDonough for violating roster rules during the 2020 season. The club had signed [[Blaise Matuidi]] and [[Andrés Reyes (footballer, born 1999)|Andrés Reyes]] using targeted [[allocation money]] (TAM) to comply with salary cap requirements and avoid using its three [[Designated Player Rule|Designated Player]] slots, but were found to have exceeded the TAM maximum of $1.61 million per player. MLS fined the club $2 million and reduced its allocation dollars by $2.27 million for the 2022 and 2023 seasons, while Mas was fined $250,000 and McDonough was suspended from league activities through the end of the 2022 season.{{cite press release |date=May 28, 2021 |title=MLS Announces Sanctions for Inter Miami CF Violating League Salary Budget and Roster Guidelines |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/news/mls-announces-sanctions-for-inter-miami-cf-violating-league-salary-budget-and-ro |publisher=Major League Soccer |accessdate=June 16, 2021}} Prior to the announcement, Matuidi was reclassified as a Designated Player by taking the slot occupied by [[Matías Pellegrini]], who was loaned to [[Fort Lauderdale CF]] after his contract was bought out by the club.{{cite news |last=Kaufman |first=Michelle |date=May 28, 2021 |title=MLS slaps Inter Miami with record $2 million fine for violating roster rules in 2020 |url=https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/inter-miami/article251746813.html |work=The Miami Herald |accessdate=June 16, 2021}} ==Colors and badge== The Miami Beckham United group unveiled the team's name and colors on September 5, 2018. The name was announced as Club Internacional de Fútbol Miami (Inter Miami CF). The [[Crest (heraldry)|crest]], designed in style and colors that recall the city's [[Art Deco]] [[architecture|architectural]] tradition, displays two [[Great blue heron|great white herons]] with interlocking legs forming a letter ''M''. Between the herons is an eclipse, the sun bearing seven rays in an homage to the number Beckham often wore as a player.{{cite news|last=Gonzalez|first=Roger|title=David Beckham's Miami MLS team unveils unique logo, color scheme and new name|url=https://www.cbssports.com/soccer/news/david-beckhams-miami-mls-team-unveils-unique-logo-color-scheme-and-new-name/|work=[[CBS Sports]]|date=September 5, 2018|access-date=September 5, 2018}} The team colors are pink, black and white.{{cite news|title=One Year Ago: The story of the Inter Miami CF brand|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/en/post/2019/09/19/one-year-ago-story-inter-miami-cf-brand-0|website=InterMiamiCF.com|publisher=MLS Digital|date=September 19, 2019|access-date=November 13, 2019}}{{cite news|last1=Phillips|first1=Doug|last2=Lerner|first2=Keven|title=Inter Miami: David Beckham's MLS team unveils name and crest|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/soccer/fl-sp-miami-soccer-team-crest-20180905-story.html|newspaper=Sun-Sentinel|date=September 5, 2018|access-date=September 5, 2018}} The [[Heraldry#The heraldic achievement|full achievement]] displays the team name encircling all with the Roman numerals ''MMXX'' representing the year 2020, the inaugural season of play.{{cite news|title=Beckham's MLS team named Inter Miami CF|url=http://kwese.espn.com/football/major-league-soccer/story/3624401/david-beckhams-mls-team-named-inter-miami-cf-ahead-of-2020-season-launch|publisher=ESPN|date=September 5, 2018|access-date=September 12, 2018}} The species of the birds in the crest was the subject of debate after its announcement and unveiling, with some speculating them to be [[flamingo]]s and [[egret]]s.{{cite news |last=Bunch |first=Matthew |date=September 18, 2018 |title=Inter Miami CF logo explained in social media video |url=http://magiccity.soccer/2018/09/18/inter-miami-cf-logo-explained-in-social-media-video/ |work=Magic City Soccer |access-date=September 18, 2018}} The team later announced that the birds are white herons.{{Cite web|date=September 6, 2018|title=InterMiami Soccer Club Crest Carries Bird That Is South Florida's Own|url=https://www.wlrn.org/news/2018-09-06/intermiami-soccer-club-crest-carries-bird-that-is-south-floridas-own|access-date=June 2, 2021|website=WLRN|language=en}} The club's name has been the subject of a [[trademark]] dispute with Italian club [[Inter Milan]], which had filed a claim with the [[U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]] for the protected use of "Inter" in 2014. MLS filed an objection to the trademark claim in April 2019, arguing that the name "Inter" was generic due to its use by [[Inter (disambiguation)#Association football clubs|other clubs]] and could not be claimed exclusively.{{cite news |last=McCann |first=Michael |date=April 4, 2019 |title=Inter Miami, MLS Go on Attack in Trademark Opposition to Inter Milan |url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2019/04/04/inter-milan-miami-trademark-rights-mls-expansion-team-name-beckham |work=Sports Illustrated |accessdate=February 8, 2021}} {{Asof|2021}}, the case continues.{{cite web |url=https://www.law.com/dailybusinessreview/2021/01/04/inter-milan-first-round-trademark-win-over-inter-miami-stands/?slreturn=20210427103633 |title=Inter Milan First Round Trademark Win Over Inter Miami Stands |first=David |last=Winker |date=January 4, 2021 |website=[[law.com]]}} ==Stadium== ===Miami Freedom Park=== {{Main|Miami Freedom Park}} [[File:International Links Melreese Country Club.jpg|thumb|The Melreese Country Club is the future site for [[Miami Freedom Park]].]] In March 2020, Inter Miami began to play in Fort Lauderdale. They will continue to do so until their new stadium, to be known as [[Miami Freedom Park]], is completed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/22/sports/soccer/david-beckham-miami-mls.html|title=For David Beckham and Miami, a Bumpy Road Enters the Homestretch|last=Brenner|first=Steve|date=February 22, 2019|work=The New York Times|access-date=April 14, 2019|issn=0362-4331}} The current proposal is for a 25,000-seat stadium that would form part of Freedom Park, a mixed-use complex on the present site of the city-owned Melreese Country Club near the [[Miami International Airport]]. Approval for construction of the stadium depended on the outcome of a public [[referendum]] held on November 6, 2018.{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Craig|title=Miami commission OK's referendum on David Beckham's MLS stadium plan|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/soccer/fl-sp-mls-stadium-referendum-hearing-20180718-story.html|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|date=July 18, 2018|access-date=September 12, 2018}} The result of the referendum had roughly 60 percent of voters approving the measure to convert the city-owned golf course near the international airport into Inter Miami CF's new stadium, [[Miami Freedom Park]].{{cite news|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article220667190.html|title=Beckham scores key victory after voters endorse stadium plan in referendum}} The proposed development, to be built on {{convert|131|acre|adj=on}} public land, will include {{convert|1000000|sqft}} of office, retail and commercial space, 750 hotel rooms, {{convert|23|acre}} of public soccer fields in addition to the {{convert|10.5|acre|adj=on}} stadium, and the remaining {{convert|58|acre}} will be a public park. The owners will also make annual installments of $20 million for 30 years for improvements to public parks across the city.{{cite news|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article215013850.html|title=After Beckham's 5-year quest, the next decision on his soccer stadium is up to voters|date=July 18, 2018|first=Joey|last=Flechas|work=The Miami Herald|access-date=August 16, 2018}} The agreement still requires the approval of a four-vote supermajority of the five City of Miami commissioners. The plan had faced opposition from supporters of the golf club and many details, such as fiscal responsibility for toxic incinerator ash in the soil, remain to be worked out.{{cite news|url=https://miami.curbed.com/2018/7/20/17566436/miami-david-beckham-mls-soccer-stadium-melreese|title=Miami voters to decide fate of David Beckham's $1B soccer stadium|first=Jay|last=Koziarz|date=July 20, 2018|access-date=August 15, 2018|work=Curbed Miami}} The decision follows a lengthy exploration of options.{{cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article154621519.html|title=David Beckham wins $9 million land deal for Miami soccer stadium|website=[[Miami Herald]] |access-date=June 28, 2017}} Some locations that had previously been considered included: [[Dodge Island]] at [[PortMiami]] (2013), the [[Downtown Miami]] waterfront at [[Bicentennial Park (Miami)|Museum Park]] (2014),{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2014/05/22/4131088/david-beckham-team-to-reveal-soccer.html|title=David Beckham's latest Miami stadium plans revealed after earlier site scratched|first=Patricia|last=Mazzei|date=May 22, 2014|work=The Miami Herald}}{{cite news |title=David Beckham's MLS Stadium Is a No-Go at Downtown Miami's Museum Park, Boat Slip|first=Patricia|last=Mazzei|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2014/06/10/4169888/miami-takes-downtown-museum-park.html|work=The Miami Herald|date=June 10, 2014|access-date=June 10, 2014}} a site adjacent to [[MLB]]'s [[Marlins Park]] (2015), and a privately owned site in Miami's [[Overtown (Miami)|Overtown]] (2015–16).{{cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article68064887.html|title=David Beckham group buys private land needed for Miami soccer stadium|website=[[Miami Herald]] |access-date=November 6, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.law360.com/articles/793661/miami-stadium-land-deal-a-not-so-easy-score-for-beckham|title=Miami Stadium Land Deal A Not-So-Easy Score For Beckham - Law360|access-date=November 6, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article47939140.html|title=Beckham announces Overtown site for soccer stadium|date=December 4, 2015|newspaper=The Miami Herald}}{{cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/article48243230.html|title=MLS owners support David Beckham's proposed Overtown stadium site|website=[[Miami Herald]] |access-date=November 6, 2016}} The team also considered the [[Riccardo Silva Stadium]] at [[Florida International University]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26728226 |title=David Beckham unveils MLS stadium plans in Port of Miami |author= |date=March 25, 2014 |work=BBC Sport |access-date=March 25, 2014}}{{cite web | title = Beckham group eyes Port of Miami for MLS home | url = https://sports.yahoo.com/news/beckham-group-eyes-port-miami-203605638--mls.html |agency= Associated Press | access-date = May 24, 2014 |date=March 24, 2014}} ===DRV PNK Stadium=== {{Main|DRV PNK Stadium}} [[File:DRV PNK Stadium (51704498938).jpg|thumb|[[DRV PNK Stadium]] entrance]] DRV PNK Stadium is a soccer stadium in [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]] on the site of the former [[Lockhart Stadium]].{{cite web |title=Inter Miami CF To Make Historic MLS Home Debut on March 14, 2020 |url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/en/post/2019/11/13/inter-miami-cf-make-historic-mls-home-debut-march-14-2020 |website=InterMiamiCF.com |access-date=November 13, 2019 |date=November 13, 2019}} The stadium is oriented north–south for soccer configuration, so the sun won't be in the eyes of the goalie.{{cite news |last1=Bandell |first1=Brian |title=David Beckham wants MLS team to play initial seasons in Fort Lauderdale at Lockhart Stadium |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/news/2019/03/14/david-beckham-wants-mls-team-to-play-initial.html |access-date=November 7, 2019 |work=[[South Florida Business Journal]] |date=March 14, 2019}} The stadium is the primary headquarters for the team and its youth academy in addition to further training grounds. The [[Fort Lauderdale Strikers (2006–2016)|Fort Lauderdale Strikers]] announced in 2016 that they were moving out of Lockhart Stadium,{{Cite news |url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/soccer/fort-lauderdale-strikers/fl-fort-lauderdale-strikers-to-leave-lockhart-0715-20160714-story.html |title=Strikers leaving longtime home at Lockhart |last2=Heizer |first1=Larry |last1=Barszewski |first2=Pedro |work=[[Sun-Sentinel]] |access-date=May 24, 2018 |date=July 14, 2016}} after which the stadium fell into a state of disrepair.{{Cite web |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2019/04/03/inter-miami-cleared-begin-demolition-old-lockhart-stadium |title=Inter Miami cleared to begin demolition of old Lockhart Stadium |last=Boehm |first=Charles |publisher=MLS Soccer |access-date=April 13, 2019 |date=April 3, 2019}} In late January 2019, Inter Miami announced its intentions to pursue the Lockhart Stadium site to serve as the club's training ground for its first team, [[USL League One]] reserve team [[Fort Lauderdale CF]], and youth academy. The development would also include an 18,000-seat stadium, which will serve as the permanent home of Fort Lauderdale CF and as the interim home for Inter Miami for at least the first two seasons while the [[Miami Freedom Park]] stadium is under construction.{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/sports/newsletter/2020-03-16/soccer-newsletter-coronavirus-soccer|title=Soccer newsletter: Coronavirus leads to a death in the soccer world|date=March 17, 2020|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=April 27, 2020}} The Fort Lauderdale city council unanimously approved Inter Miami's bid for the Lockhart Stadium site in March 2019. In April, the Fort Lauderdale City Commission cleared Inter Miami to begin the demolition process.{{cite web |title=Demolition Of Fort Lauderdale's Lockhart Underway |url=https://miami.cbslocal.com/2019/05/08/demolition-of-fort-lauderdales-lockhart-stadium-set-to-begin/ |publisher=[[WFOR-TV]] |date=May 8, 2019}} On July 9, 2019, the Fort Lauderdale City Commission unanimously approved a 50-year lease agreement for the Lockhart Stadium site with Inter Miami; under the terms of the agreement, the city will retain ownership of the property while the soccer club will be responsible for the construction, operation, and maintenance of the new facilities.{{cite web |last1=Boehm |first1=Charles |title=City of Fort Lauderdale approves Inter Miami stadium, training facility |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2019/07/10/city-fort-lauderdale-approves-inter-miami-stadium-training-facility |publisher=MLS Soccer |access-date=July 10, 2019 |date=July 10, 2019}} ===Training complex=== In late January 2019, the club announced its intentions to pursue the [[Lockhart Stadium]] site in [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida|Fort Lauderdale]] to serve as the club's training ground for its first team, youth academy, and future [[United Soccer League]] (USL) team.{{Cite web|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2019/01/28/inter-miami-presents-proposal-revitalize-historic-lockhart-stadium-site|title=Inter Miami Presents Proposal to Revitalize Historic Lockhart Stadium Site|last=MLS Communications|date=January 28, 2019|website=MLS Soccer|access-date=January 28, 2019}} The new training complex consist of over {{convert|30|acre}} of grass and green space, that will include various amenities such as a park, youth soccer fields, and a community center. Upon completion, the complex is used as the permanent training facilities for all levels of Inter Miami's teams ranging from their Youth Academy teams and USL League One team to the first team that plays in MLS.{{Cite web|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/club/facilities/training-complex|title=Training Complex of Inter Miami CF|last=Inter Miami CF Website|date=October 9, 2019|website=MLS Soccer|access-date=January 13, 2020}} ==Ownership== The ownership group behind the franchise was first formed in 2013 as Miami Beckham United, though it now trades under the name Miami Freedom Park LLC.{{cite news|last=Flechas|first=Joey|title=Revised terms for Beckham soccer stadium complex offer city concessions, more money|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article215021850.html|newspaper=[[The Miami Herald]]|date=July 17, 2018|access-date=August 20, 2018}} The original ownership group was led by Miami-based Bolivian businessman [[Marcelo Claure]],{{cite news|last=Madigan|first=Nick|title=Hurdles Ahead for Beckham and M.L.S. in Miami|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/06/sports/soccer/david-beckham-confirms-miami-plans-but-hurdles-remain.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 6, 2014|access-date=September 12, 2018}} while [[Masayoshi Son]] and brothers [[MasTec|Jorge and Jose Mas]] were added to the ownership group in 2017.{{cite news|title=Three new owners added to David Beckham's Miami expansion team|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2017/12/14/three-new-owners-added-david-beckhams-miami-expansion-team|website=MLSsoccer.com|publisher=MLS Digital|date=December 14, 2017|access-date=August 20, 2018}} The effort originated in a contract [[David Beckham]] signed with MLS in 2007; he joined [[LA Galaxy]] and negotiated an option to own an [[Expansion of Major League Soccer|expansion team]] at a discounted [[franchise fee]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/news/inter-miami-cf-announces-mas-brothers-beckham-increase-ownership-stake-in-the-cl|title=Inter Miami CF Announces Mas Brothers, Beckham Increase Ownership Stake in the Club | Inter Miami CF|website=intermiamicf|accessdate=September 20, 2021}} On September 17, 2021, it was announced that Beckham and the Mas brothers had bought out Claure and Son's stakes in the ownership group.{{cite web|url=https://www.espn.com/soccer/inter-miami-cf/story/4477117/david-beckham-increases-inter-miami-ownership-stake|title=David Beckham increases Inter Miami ownership stake|website=ESPN.com|date=September 17, 2021}} [[Ares Management]] was also added to the ownership group.{{cite web|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/news/david-beckham-mas-brothers-increase-ownership-stake-in-inter-miami-cf|title=David Beckham, Mas brothers increase ownership stake in Inter Miami CF|website=MLSSoccer.com|date=September 17, 2021}} ==Supporters== The club has three official supporters groups: Siege, Southern Legion, and Vice City 1896.{{Cite This team allows the club to prepare future players with quality competition in hopes of being called up to the first team. The unnamed League One Miami team will train at the training facilities of [[Inter Miami CF Stadium]].{{Cite web |title=USL League One |work=Inter Miami CF |access-date=January 12, 2020|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/en/post/2019/10/09/inter-miami-cf-field-usl-league-one-team-2020}} The team was to open their inaugural season on March 27, 2020, against [[Union Omaha]] at Inter Miami CF Stadium but the match was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.{{Cite web |title=USL League One Schedule |access-date=January 12, 2020|url=https://www.uslleagueone.com/league-schedule}} On February 24, 2022, Fort Lauderdale CF announced that the team had rebranded as [[Inter Miami CF II]] ahead of their move to the [[MLS Next Pro]], the new reserve league for MLS teams.{{cite web |title=Inter Miami CF Unveils MLS NEXT Pro Team Name, Initial Roster and Full Schedule |url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/news/inter-miami-cf-unveils-mls-next-pro-team-name-initial-roster-and-full-schedule |publisher=Inter Miami CF}} === Academy === The Inter Miami CF Academy is the official [[youth system|youth academy and development system]] of Inter Miami CF that was established in 2019.{{Cite web |title=IMCF Academy |work=Academy |access-date=January 12, 2020|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/en/academy/about}} The academy consists of various levels of age groups, ranging from U-12 to U-17. These teams will also train at the training grounds in [[Inter Miami CF Stadium]] alongside their MLS and USL League One counterparts. All of Inter Miami's youth teams compete in the [[MLS Next]] soccer league as of the inaugural 2022 season. The system covers the under-12, under-13, under-14, under-15, and under-17 age groups.https://www.intermiamicf.com/academy/about == Media == The team's first three matches in the 2020 season were assigned to national broadcasts; a broadcast deal was not announced before the suspension of play due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but the team did announce that [[Ray Hudson]] will serve as color commentator,{{Cite web|url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2020/03/05/ray-hudson-inter-miami-broadcast-team-mls|title=Ray Hudson to Broadcast Inter Miami Matches|last=Creditor|first=Avi|website=Sports Illustrated|access-date=March 8, 2020}} Andres Cordero will serve as the play-by-play commentator, joined by [[Fernando Fiore]] as the host, and [[Kaylyn Kyle]] as the sideline reporter.{{Cite web|url=https://www.intermiamicf.com/en/post/2020/03/26/dynamic-talent-group-hired-enhance-inter-miami-cf-s-digital-presence|title=Inter Miami announces broadcast team|website=Inter Miami CF|access-date=March 27, 2020}} On April 3, 2020, the club announced a regional English-language television deal with [[CBS Television Stations]], under which its regional matches will air on [[MyNetworkTV]] affiliate [[WBFS-TV]], with selected matches airing on [[CBS]] station [[WFOR-TV]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.sportspromedia.com/news/inter-miami-tv-rights-cbs-english-language|title=Inter Miami lock in local TV rights deal with CBS|website= SportsPro Media|access-date=April 15, 2020}} Then on April 30, the club announced a Spanish rights deal with [[Univision]], where games will be aired on its TV affiliate [[WAMI-DT|WAMI]] and radio affiliate [[WQBA]], with a broadcast team consisting of Ramses Sandoval, {{ill|Luis Omar Tapia|es}}, {{ill|Daniel Nohra|es}}, {{ill|Diego Balado|es}}, Nicholas Cantor and Tony Cherchi.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/soccer/inter-miami/fl-sp-inter-miami-univision-miami-20200430-ynnlztd7fjekjnrginhfpjlujq-story.html|title=Inter Miami announce Spanish deal with
